an3.38:4.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, the Lord of Gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-three, recited this verse:
an3.38:5.4: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,
an3.38:5.5: and the eighth day of the fortnight,
an3.38:5.6: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’
an3.38:6.1: But that verse was poorly sung by Sakka, the Lord of Gods, not well sung; poorly spoken, not well spoken.
an3.38:6.3: Because Sakka, the Lord of Gods, is not exempt from birth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. He is not exempt from suffering, I say.
an3.38:7.1: But for a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has lived the spiritual life, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their purpose, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through final knowledge—it is appropriate to say:
an3.38:8.4: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,
an3.38:8.5: and the eighth day of the fortnight,
an3.38:8.6: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’
an3.38:9.2: Because that mendicant is exempt from birth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. He is exempt from suffering, I say.”
